Brian wrote:
>> okay, i'm confused about "black box" and "white box" testing.
>> ...
>> And if this is "black box" testing, what the heck counts as "white box"
>> testing?

Ok, basically white box testing is nothing more than testing basic software
components
or integrated components! And that often by looking into the source code...

The only one who can see the code is the developer himself, so it's a task
for developers, they look beyond the boundaries of modules/components, so
that's why they call it white box instead of black box.

As a developer you have to analyze your coding (statements, paths, ...)
and build YOUR  "white" test cases adequately.

Then of course you have your functional test cases, because you had a
description of what
your component should do, and these are quite "black" test cases.

What I' m trying to say is: YOU're doing something of both, but it's called
nevertheless
white box testing (for the developer). And so does JUnit, a little bit of
both!
But I always would position JUnit as a white box tool. The unit is WHAT I'm
testing,
I do it primarily by my METHOD of looking inside the code.
I do it in my development ENVIRONMENT, so it's a developer test.
That's white box testing!

Tom
subject: Antwort: [junit] black box or white box?
